metadata.title: Highly selective removal of Zn(II) ion from hot-dip galvanizing pickling waste with amino-functionalized Fe3O4@SiO2 magnetic nano-adsorbent

sections.text:
* Corresponding authors:Lihong Tang Tel:13808733050 E-mail addresses: luckyman@163.com, 64862193@qq.com .
1
Zn(II) ion from hot-dip galvanizing pickling waste in the presence of Fe(II). These hot-dip galvanizing pickling waste mainly contain ZnCl2 and FeCl2 in aqueous HCl media. The properties of this magnetic adsorbent were examined by transmission electron microscopy (TEM), powder X-ray diffraction (XRD), infrared spectrometer (FT-IR) and BET surface area measurements. Various factors influencing the adsorption of Zn(II) ion such as initial concentration of metal ions, the amount of adsorbent, pH value of the solutions, the concentration of coexisting iron ion were investigated by batch experiments.The results indicated that the adsorption equilibrium data obeyed the Freundlich model with maximum adsorption capacities for Zn(II) to 169.5 mg/g. The maximum adsorption occurred at pH 5 ± 0.1 and Fe(II) interferences had no obvious influence. This work provides a potential and unique technique for zinc ion removal from hot-dip galvanizing pickling waste. Keywords: Fe3O4/SiO2 nanoparticles. amino modification. hot-dip galvanizing pickling waste. adsorption zinc

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
With the rapid development of high voltage transmission, transportation and telecommunications, the demand for steel protection is higher and higher, along with hot-dip galvanizing also increases accordingly. Nowadays, hot-dip galvanizing is one of the most widespread methods for improving the corrosion resistance of various types of steel [1-2]. The hot-dip galvanizing process have a succession of stages such as rinsing, degreasing, and galvanizing itself, however, during this progress spent pickling acid generates a succession of effluents that it mainly consists of 5 to 200 g/L zinc(II), 60 to 150 g/L iron (mainly iron(II)), and 10 to 80 g/L hydrochloric acid [3-5], which will give rise to some environmental problems. Traditional treatment methods based on the precipitation and neutralization that spent pickling acid were neutralized to precipitate a mixture of iron and zinc hydroxides with lime, which was discarded into landfill site [6]. With the improvement of people's consciousness of environmental protection and tighter environmental legislation, recovery and regeneration of metals in spending pickling solutions has become an inevitable trend. Particularly, zinc is a very expensive metal in spent pickling acid.
Up to now there are different traditional methods for selective removal of Zn(II) ion from hot-dip galvanizing pickling waste, have been reported in literature, such as solvent extraction [7-10], Ion-exchange membrane [11], Crystallization [12-13], membrane based solvent extraction [14], anion exchange and membrane electrowinning [15-17], etc., have been researched. Nevertheless, extraction is the most commonly used method for treatment hot-dip galvanizing pickling waste. Extraction refers to that takes advantage of compound solubility and distribution coefficient of different in two kinds of immiscible with each other or slightly soluble solvent, to allow possible diffusivemass transfer of solutes from one solvent into another, and then repeat multiple extractions. Thus enrichment of solute are finally extracted. The utilization of various extractants has also been reported for zinc extraction from chloride solutions, such as: phosphonium ionic liquid Cyphos IL 101 [7], di-2-ethylhexyl phosphoric acid [8], TBP diluted in ShellSol 2046 [10] and pyridinecarboxamides [18]. We can easily find that extracting agent is generally of nitrogen and phosphorus organic solvents, throughout these above-mentioned extraction agent. However, these extraction agent are mostly flammable, volatile and causes harm to the environment and human health. In addition, the process of extraction needs to be done under the close supervision of staff, and extraction equipment is also very expensive. So, the development and application of traditional extraction methods seems to meet a tightest bottleneck.
Along with the development of modern waste water treatment, the recycling of metals from wastewater is an
important and interesting field no matter in industry or scientific research. The method, the recycling of metals from wastewater by modified superparamagnetic nanoparticles adsorbent, acceleratedly walked into the researchers' vision. The modified superparamagnetic Fe3O4 nanoparticles adsorbent have been successfully applied to various kinds of removal of heavy metals from wastewater such as copper, zinc, mercury, cobalt, chromium or lead, adsorption of Zn (II) using Fe3O4@ APS@ AA-co-CA as adsorbent [19], selective separation of Cd (II)/（Na + , K + , Mg 2+ ） mixtures using magnetic hydroxyapatite nanoparticles [20], removal Cu(II) [21-22], selective separation of Pb(II) [23], removal and recovery of Hg(II) [24]. Compared with traditional solvent extraction, these superparamagnetic modified nanoparticle adsorption methods are more economic, more cost effective and less environmental impact than traditional solvent extraction method.
In this study, (3-aminopropyl)-triethoxysilane (a common silanizing reagent) were used as surface modification reagents, modify Fe3O4@SiO2 get a novel amino-functionalized Fe3O4@SiO2 nano-sorbents (Fe3O4@SiO2–NH2) for selective removal of Zn(II) ion from hot-dip galvanizing pickling wastewater. We characterized the Fe3O4@SiO2–NH2 nano-sorbents with several instruments and the influences of different parameters on the adsorption efficiency were investigated.
2. Materials and methods 2.1. Materials
Iron(III) chloride hexahydrate (FeCl3·6H2O, 99%), Sodium citrate dihydrate (Na3Cit, 99%), Sodium acetate (NaOAc, 99%) and aqueous ammonium hydroxide (NH4OH, 25 wt %), Ethylene glycol (EG), hydrochloric acid (HCl, 36 wt %), sodium hydroxide (NaOH pellets), and (3-aminopropyl)-triethoxysilane (APTMS), zinc(II) [Zn(NO3)2·6H2O], tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) were purchased from Tianjin ZhiYuan Reagent Co.,Ltd in high purity Grade. All reagents used in the experiment were analytical reagent grade and used as received without further purification.
2.2. Synthesis of Fe3O4@SiO2-NH2
The Fe3O4 particles were prepared by a solvothermal method as previously reported [23]. Briefly, Na3Cit (1.5 g), NaOAc (4.0 g) and FeCl3.6H2O (1.62 g) were dissolved in EG (60 mL), after vigorous mechanical stirring for 1 h, the obtained yellow solution was transferred to Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave (100 mL), then sealed and heated at 200 °C in muffle furnace to improve the crystallinity of Fe3O4 and its magnetic property. After reaction for 8 h, the autoclave was cooled to room temperature. The obtained black Fe3O4 nanoparticles suspension were collected by an external magnetic field and washed three times with deionized water. Finally, the products were re-dispersed in 80 mL water for further use.
The coating of SiO2 onto Fe3O4 was completed. First, 200 mL of anhydrous ethanol and 10mL of pure water were placed into a 250-ml three-necked flask, and the above prepared Fe3O4 nanoparticles were added, ultrasonic treatment for 1h. Then the suspension was heated to 323 K, and 2ml of TEOS (Tetraethyl orthosilicate 99.999%, Tianjin ZhiYuan Reagent Co.,Ltd in high purity Grade) was dropped into the suspension under a nitrogen flow (40 ml/min) protection with vigorous mechanical stirring for 5 h. The mixture was stored statically for 2 h. Finally, the obtained Fe3O4@SiO2 nanoparticles were washed three times with deionized water under the help of magnetic separation. The experimental results suggest that synthesis of the sample was directly used for the next step after a wash, had better not drying, because of it is easy to cause hard aggregations for dying.
The amine functional group on the Fe3O4@SiO2 was synthesized using APTMS. For this analysis, the functionalized Fe3O4@SiO2 nanoparticles were prepared, the synthesized Fe3O4@SiO2 nanoparticles were dispersed into 100 mL of deionized water. The suspension was transferred in a 250-ml three-necked flask, and then was ultrasonically dispersed for 1 h. Next 4.5 mL of APTMS were added. The mixture was heated to 323 K and mechanical stirring for 10 h under a nitrogen atmosphere. Subsequently, the resulted Fe3O4@SiO2-NH2 nanoparticles were

2.3. Adsorbent characterization
Samples for transmission electron microscopy (TEM) were obtained by embedding composite particles in an epoxy resin, generating a flat surface by cross-sectional polishing (JEOL SM-09010 cross section polisher), and cutting a lamella with a focused Ga-ion beam (FEI Co. 200 3D focused ion beam quanta). TEM, high-resolution TEM (HRTEM), and scanning TEM (STEM) with EDX (STEM-EDX) were carried out using a JEOL JEM2010 microscope. Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) was carried out on KBr pellets, and diffuse-reflectance FTIR (DRIFT) spectroscopy on powder samples with a Nicolet MagnaIR760 spectrometer. X-ray diffraction (XRD) was performed on vacuum-dried powder samples (Phillips PW 1730/10). The specific surface area was measured by N2 adsorption using Brunauer−Emmett−Teller (BET).
2.4. adsorption experiments of Zn(II) in the presence of Fe(II)
In all our experiments, the pH value of solution was less than 5. The part ferrous iron in hot-dip galvanizing pickling waste were observed to form precipitation of ferrous hydroxide (Fe(OH)2) when the pH of solution increased to 5, which will directly affect the adsorbing effect. And, ferrous is also susceptible to air oxidation at high pH.
Batch experiments were conducted to evaluate the adsorption efficiency of Zn(II) in the presence of Fe(II). Salts of Zn(II) and Fe(II) were dissolved in 1 L of deionized water. This was followed by 0.1 mol/L hydrochloric acid (HCl, 36 wt%) solution added drop by drop into the mixture to adjust the pH. Subsequently, a certain amount of amino-functionalized superparamagnetic Fe3O4@SiO2 nano-adsorbent was added to the mixture, and the reaction at room temperature (25°C), during the duration of this stirring. After adsorption, the bottle was placed on a magnet for 5 min to separate the sorbents from aqueous solution. When the solution became limpid, a portion of supernatant was taken, and the initial and final metal (Zn(II) and Fe(II)) concentrations were determined by AAS. 2.4.1. Effect of adsorbent amount
The effect of different amount of adsorbents were determined throughout dispersing 20 mg to 100 mg of adsorbents in 100 ml of Fe(II) solution (200 mg/L) containing 100mg/L Zn(II) and stirring continuously at 25°C for 2 h. After reaching adsorption equilibrium, the residual metal concentrations in the solutions were measured by AAS.
2.4.2. Effect of pH
A separation set of experiments were conducted to test the pH effect on adsorption of Zn(II) ions onto Fe3O4@-SiO2–NH2 with pH ranging from approximately 1.0 ± 0.1 to 5.0 ± 0.1 at 25°C for 2 h. In a typical procedure, a series of conical flasks containing 50 mg of Fe3O4@SiO2–NH2 and 100 mL Zn(II) solution of 100 mg/L and containing 200mgl/L Fe(II). The required pH was adjusted by HCl (0.1 mol/L) or NaOH (0.1 mol/L), and the pH values were measured by a pH-meter (MP511, China). After reaching adsorption equilibrium, the suspensions were separated and the residual metal concentrations were analyzed.
2.4.3. Effect of coexist iron concentration
The effect of coexisting ions Fe(II) on Zn(II) adsorption by Fe3O4@SiO2–NH2 was studied by dispersing 50 mg of adsorbents in 100 ml of Fe(II) solution (60–200 mg/L) containing 100mg/L Zn(II) at pH 5 ± 0.1 and 25°C. After separation, the residual metal concentrations in the solutions were measured by AAS.

sections.heading: 3. Results and discussion
sections.text:
3.1. Properties of prepared magnetic adsorbents
The crystalline structures of the nanoparticles were identified with XRD (Fig. 1). The XRD pattern of a standard Fe3O4 crystal with spinel structure has seven characteristic peaks at 2θ = 30.1◦, 35.5◦, 43.1◦, 53.4◦, 57.0◦, 62.6◦ and 74.3◦ that are attributed to the (2 2 0), (3 1 1), (4 0 0), (4 2 2), (5 1 1), (4 4 0) and (5 5 3) phases of Fe3O4, which match well with the database of magnetite in JCPDS (JCPDS Card: 19-629) file. Fig. 1 shows a typical XRD pattern of the Fe3O4@SiO2 sample, this pattern shows almost the same feature as that shown in Fig. 1, no diffraction peaks corresponding to SiO2 were observed because the prepared SiO2 is amorphous. The same set of characteristic peaks were also observed for Fe3O4@SiO2–NH2, indicating the stability of the crystalline phase of Fe3O4 nanoparticles during surface amino-functionalization. Apparently, the magnetite be modified with amine group, the diffraction peak become shorter and wider because of the relatively high APTMS concentration, which can be detected by other analysis.
Fig.1. Power X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of (a) Fe3O4 , (b) Fe3O4@SiO2, (c)Fe3O4@SiO2-NH2.
Fig. 2. The FT-IR spectra of Fe3O4, Fe3O4/ SiO2 and Fe3O4/SiO2–NH2 nanoparticles.
Fig. 2 shows the FT-IR spectra of pure Fe3O4, Fe3O4/ SiO2 core/shell, and Fe3O4/SiO2–NH2 nanoparticles. All
samples show broad bands at around 585 cm -1 , corresponding to the Fe–O vibration related to the magnetite phase [25]. For Fe3O4 and Fe3O4/ SiO2 nanoparticles were all shown broad bands at around 1626 and 3436 cm -1 , which should be attributed to the bending and stretching vibration of –OH from water molecules [26,27,28]. Spectra of Fe3O4@SiO2 and Fe3O4@SiO2–NH2 appeared a broad strong band at around 1077 and 802 cm -1 , which were characteristic bands of the Si–O–Si asymmetric stretching vibration and symmetric stretching vibration, reflecting the coating of silica shells on the magnetite surface [29]. Successful amino-functionalization of the silica layer on Fe3O4@SiO2 was also evidenced by the absorption at 3390 and 1620 cm -1 , attributed to the stretching and bending vibrations of amino groups [30]. These FT-IR spectra verified the formation of a silica shell onto the surface of Fe3O4 and the amino-functionalization of the silica shell.
Fig. 3. TEM images and electron diffraction patterns (inset) of a Fe3O4 and b Fe3O4@SiO2.
In order to get more direct information on particle size and morphology, typical TEM images and electron diffraction patterns (inset) of Fe3O4 and Fe3O4@SiO2 were compared and illustrated in Fig. 3. As shown in Fig. 3(a), the magnetite particles tend to aggregate. This is due to the ultrasmall size and the requirement to decrease their interface energy [31]. Careful examination Fig. 3(b) reveals that the Fe3O4@SiO2 nanoparticles are nearly in the core shell structures, with the black color showing Fe3O4 and the ash color is the silica shell. And the average diameter of
a b
Fe3O4@SiO2 nanoparticles obtained was about 80nm (Fig. 3(b)) due to by the coating of SiO2 on the surface of the magnetic core and the multiple Fe3O4 nanoparticles core embedded in the silica matrix. This indicates iron oxide have been entrapped in the silican shell successfully. Furthermore, the electron diffraction patterns of Fe3O4 and Fe3O4@SiO2 can be indexed to their crystal structure, which are consistent with from the XRD patterns result. Typical electron diffraction pattern of Fe3O4 and Fe3O4@SiO2 is shown in inset of Fig. 3.
The BET specific surface area of Fe3O4 were calculated to be 33.2 m 2 /g, after the coating procedure, the Fe3O4@SiO2 exhibit a relatively higher BET surface area of 93.2 m 2 /g due to the coating of SiO2 component. However, after the surface modification with amino, the specific surface area of Fe3O4@SiO2-NH2 decreased to 75.6 m 2 /g. This indicates that some amino molecules cross-linked with the hydroxy groups of silica moieties on Fe3O4@SiO2, which would result in the decrease of the surface area. This is in accord with the results reported by Ren et al [32].
The Fe3O4@SiO2–NH2 magnetic nano-adsorbent showed good water dispersion in solvents and exhibited a strong magnetization in the presence of a magnetic field. As shown in Fig. 4a, the Fe3O4@SiO2–NH2 were dispersed in water under normal conditions by sonication for several minutes. The magnetic response of the nano-adsorbent was tested by placing a magnet near the glass vial. As shown in Fig. 4b, the nano-adsorbent were attracted rapidly to the side of the magnet, resulting in a clear and transparent solution. Thus they can easily be removed under an external magnetic field, which contributed to making them recyclable.
Fig. 4. Photographs of dispersed in aqueous solution and magnetic separation of magnetic nano-adsorbent : without external magnetic field(a),and with external magnetic field(b).
3.2. Sorption study 3.2.1. Effect of adsorbent amount
In order to obtain the optimum adsorbent amount, the effect of different amount of adsorbents on the adsorption quantities of Zn(II) was presented in Fig. 5. The adsorption results suggest that the adsorption quantities of Zn(II) clearly increases with the increasing of adsorbent amount at the beginning. When the amount of the adsorbent was 50 mg, the adsorption amount reached maximum. However, the adsorption quantities of Zn(II) remarkably decrease as the adsorbent amount increasing from 50 mg to 100 mg. The reason for this phenomenon was that, the number of unoccupied active adsorption sites grew. Moreover, high dosage may result in aggregation of the adsorbents [33]. Hence, this dosage was chosen in the following experiments.
a b
Fig. 5. The effect of different amount of adsorbents on the adsorption quantities of Zn(II). (Reaction conditions: solution pH:5; equilibrium time: 2h; teamperature: 25°C; Initial concentration of Zn(II) ions; 100mg/L; solution volume: 100mL.)
3.2.2. Effect of pH
In order to illustrate the effect of solution pH on the adsorption of Zn(II) ions, amino-functionalized magnetic nanoparticles was mixed with solutions containing 100 mg/L of Zn and 200 mg/L of Fe ions at 25°C and with pH ranging from approximately 1.0 ± 0.1 to 5.0 ± 0.1. The pH values were adjusted by HCl (0.1 mol/Lol.L −1 ) and NaOH (0.1 mol/Lol.L −1 ). The concentrations of metal ions in the solutions were detected after 2 h. The relationship between the initial pH values and the amount of heavy metals adsorbed on Fe3O4@SiO2–NH2 adsorbents was shown in Fig. 6. It was observed that the adsorption capacity increased with increasing solution pH. At lower pH values, The obvious decreasing of removals might be attributed to the electrostatic repulsion between the protonated amine group of Fe3O4@SiO2–NH2 surface and the positive metal ions [34]. As the pH value increased, the adsorption capacity of Zn(II) ion onto the Fe3O4@SiO2–NH2 was enhanced because the protonated groups were deprotonated. Therefore, Zn(II) adsorption on the magnetic nanoadsorbent is greater at high pH and increases with increasing pH.
Fig. 6. Effect of pH on the adsorption of Zn(II) ions by the amino-functionalized nanoparticles. (Initial concentration of Zn(II) ions: 100mg/L; nanoparticles: 50 mg; solution volume: 100mL.)

The hot-dip galvanizing process spent pickling acid generates a succession of effluents that it mainly consists of 5 to 200 g/L zinc(II), 60 to 150 g/L iron (mainly iron(II)), and 10 to 80 g/L hydrochloric acid [3-5]. To investigate the effect of coexist iron on zinc adsorption on Fe3O4@SiO2–NH2 sorbents, different concentrations of iron ions are added to the solution. The adsorption capacity of zinc on Fe3O4@SiO2–NH2 in the absence and presence of iron are presented in Fig. 7. The obtained results showed that interferences had no obvious influence, when concentrations of irons enhanced from 60 to 200 mg/L, indicating the adsorbent can selective adsorption of zinc in the hot-dip galvanizing solution.
Fig. 7. Effect of coexisting iron(II) ion on adsorption of zinc on Fe3O4@SiO2–NH2 sorbent. (Reaction conditions: solution pH:5; equilibrium time: 2h; teamperature: 25°C; Initial concentration of Zn(II) ions: 100mg/L; nanoparticles: 50 mg; solution volume: 100mL.)
3.2.4. Sorption isotherms
To understand the adsorption mechanism of Zn(II) ions on the nano-adsorbent which is very important for the design of adsorption systems, the adsorption data were constructed by adsorption isothermal models. Therefore, both Langmuir and Freundlich adsorption isotherms were employed to normalize the adsorption data. The Langmuir model predicts the adsorption of molecule is a monolayer adsorption, with no side interaction among adsorbed molecule. It also assumes that the adsorption of adsorbent surface is uniform. The Freundlich model considers the existence of a multilayered structure. The results are shown in Fig. 8. The results showed that the values of correlation coefficient for the Langmuir(Fig. 8a) and Freundlich(Fig. 8b) were 0.8094 and 0.9923 respectively, which demonstrated the Freundlich model fitted better than the Langmuir model, demonstrating that the adsorption of Zn 2+ onto Fe3O4@SiO2–NH2 can be considered to be a multilayer adsorption process. The Langmuir and Freundlich isotherm parameters were calculated and are summarized in Table 1. From Table 1, the calculated maximum adsorption capacity (qm) of 169.5 mg/g for Zn(II).

3.3. Desorption and regeneration experiment
The reusability of adsorbents is of great importance factor in evaluating their potential applications. Therefore, it is necessary to repeated use of an adsorbent under proper conditions. In order to investigate the regeneration capacity of adsorbent, at first desorption experiments were performed under batch experimental conditions. In this study, acid solution, including acetic acid, hydrochloric acid, sulfuric acid and nitric acid (all at 0.1 mol/L concentration), was chosen as the desorbing agent. The results show that hydrochloric acid is the best regeneration agent. The desorption efficiency of Zn(II) increased with the increase of hydrochloric acid concentration, but gradually reached a constant value at higher hydrochloric acid concentrations up to 1 mol/L, the desorption ratio achieve maximum. This phenomenon may be attributed to the reversible process of cationic exchange between the magnetic zinc of nano-adsorbents surface and hydrogen ion(H + ) of the solution. The recyclability of adsorbents was shown in Fig. 9.
The regeneration of the magnetic nano-adsorbent for zinc ion adsorption was accordingly carried out by repeating the adsorption-desorption cycle five times using the same magnetic nano-adsorbent. These results in this study suggest that the adsorption capacity of magnetic nano-adsorbent dropped slightly with the increase of the times of adsorption. However, the Fe3O4@SiO2–NH2 adsorbent still had a high regeneration capacity after five adsorption–desorption cycles, and indicate that the Fe3O4@SiO2–NH2 is a promising adsorbent.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
In this study, a highly selective amino-functionalized Fe3O4@SiO2 magnetic nano-adsorbent was prepared with high magnetic properties and investigated towards the removal of Zn(II) ion from hot-dip galvanizing pickling waste. Its structure was characterized by FT-IR, XRD, TEM and BET analysis. Both FT-IR and TEM indicates iron oxide have entrapped in the silican shell successfully. These FT-IR spectra verified the amino-functionalization of the silica shell. The factors of pH, initial concentration and coexisting iron ion were studied. The results indicate that the absorption capacity of the absorbent towards zinc was consisted with the Freundlich model with maximum adsorption capacities for Zn(II) to 169.5 mg/g. The maximum adsorption occurred at pH 5 ± 0.1 and Fe(II) interferences had no obvious influence. When the amount of the adsorbent was 50 mg, the adsorption amount reached maximum. This nano-adsorbent shows notable advantages including easy separation and recyclability.

metadata.abstractText: Amino-functionalized Fe3O4@SiO2 magnetic nano-adsorbent was used as a novel sorbent to highly selective removal of Zn(II) ion from hot-dip galvanizing pickling waste in the presence of Fe(II). These hot-dip galvanizing pickling waste mainly contain ZnCl2 and FeCl2 in aqueous HCl media. The properties of this magnetic adsorbent were examined by transmission electron microscopy (TEM), powder X-ray diffraction (XRD), infrared spectrometer (FT-IR) and BET surface area measurements. Various factors influencing the adsorption of Zn(II) ion such as initial concentration of metal ions, the amount of adsorbent, pH value of the solutions, the concentration of coexisting iron ion were investigated by batch experiments.The results indicated that the adsorption equilibrium data obeyed the Freundlich model with maximum adsorption capacities for Zn(II) to 169.5 mg/g. The maximum adsorption occurred at pH 5 ± 0.1 and Fe(II) interferences had no obvious influence. This work provides a potential and unique technique for zinc ion removal from hot-dip galvanizing pickling waste.
